On Thu, Jan 22, 2009 at 1:12 PM, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@...> wrote:

>   RJ
> I think the answers will vary from individual to individual based on thier
> beliefs. As for me personally I grew up surrounded by unexplained events and
> my parents tried to ignore the things that they couldnt see because if you
> ignore it then it doesnt exist right? But there comes a time when the child
> grows up and forms thier own ideas and beliefs. Personally speaking once I
> reached adulthood there were many other people who experienced the same
> things I did in that house so I began to see that there was more to it than
> just a childs imagination.
>
> Most religions are based upon the idea that there is a higher power, that
> we all have spirits, and that there is something beyond this life. To say
> that someone is wrong for belief in ghosts I would have to say that billions
> of others are wrong for having belief at all. I dont think bad of a parent
> who takes their kids off to church every sunday nor do I think badly about a
> parent who spends some time doing ITC. Telling a child that there is more
> than what the eye can see, more than what the ears can hear, is giving them
> the basics for growing up with a mind thats open to possibility. What they
> do with that is up to them individually.
>
> I worry more about the kids who grow up with parents who are alchoholics,
> drug addicts, liars, thieves, abusers, etcetera.. than anyone.
>
> As for if the effect is positive or negative, I think that has to do with
> the intent or the approach taken by each individual whether it be ITC,
> religion, or life in general.
>
> Misty
